Ok, I've sussed it.  This doesn't work with mkv2vob.  Using the other guys suggestion which wasn't very clear I've got it to accept it.  Download mkvmergeGUI, when you add the file you'll need to click on the added file to get the options working (otherwise they're greyed out like mentioned by other guy).  So click on prince of persia video and then on the extra options tab click on compression, scroll to none.  Click on Prince of persia audio, extra options, compression scroll to none then use merge tab at top.  It'll create another mkv file with (1) after the title.  Chuck that in mkv2vob an roberts your mothers brother!

Downloaded this file. It caused my windows explorer to go haywire. I was unable to delete. Even though I never ran it, it would say the program was being run by windows explorer and not allow it to be deleted. I had to use UltraExplorer and have it opened when I ended the task of Windows explorer in order to remove.

Do not trust this download!!

I am not sure why others may not have had issues with this. However this download screws with the computer and I would not trust it.

I could not rename the folder or delete it. When I tried it would say the program is already running in Windows Explorer. I had not started the file or anything to play it.

It even caused my windows explorer to not load up properly. I had to get UltraExplorer to move through my computer folders.

The only way I was able to remove this file was by opening Ultra Explorer. Then using task manager I ended the process for Windows Explorer. This closed down my desktop, except for the UltraExplorer I already had running. This then allowed me to delete the folder it was in.

I cut and paste my downloads from a download file on my drive to a network drive. That is how I found out the file could not be deleted. I highly recommend using a different torrent and not trusting Torrents by AiTB.

Maybe someone can help me out here....sometimes when I download movies such as this one, I cannot do anything with it....I am trying to watch it on my big screen TV, but when I go to put it on a external hard drive it says "not enough free disk space" yet I have 596 GB left on the drive, and it won't let me put a 6 GB file on it. I have had this problem before, it usually happens with HD movies. And, no it isn't just my computer, I have tested this theory. So what I am having to do is put the file through HandBrake and do a damn 20 something hour re-encode just so I can get it off the computer. Its like I have to tell the file what size it is, because even though it says it 6 GB, it really doesn't know. The file thinks it is an infinite number of GBs.

@Thomps6o: Most probably your external hard drive is formatted to FAT32 file system and cannot support files larger than 2GB. Re-format it to NTFS and you should be ok (right click on the hard drive's icon and select format with the NTFS enabled). You will have to take a back up first.
